column1: Maple Valley is a city in King County
column6: 202 as of 2019. The city functions as a commuter town for residents

column1: The area was settled in 1879 by three men who were improving a trail and brought their families in. When a name for a future community was proposed
column2: the names Vine Maple Valley and Maple Ridge were suggested. A vote was taken by writing the names on slips of paper and placing them in a hat. Vine Maple Valley won by 2/3
column3: but the word "Vine" was later cut by the post office because it made the name too long.The town's early history mainly had to do with coal
column5: and a railroad that ran through town. Coal was brought in from Black Diamond to the south
column6: but the town itself also mined coal from Cedar Mountain. The mine was used as late as 1947.

column1: Rail workers for lines like the Northern Pacific Railroad and the Cedar River Watershed
column2: closed off by the City of Seattle
column3: meant more workers for those things. More residents meant more lumber milling. More lumber milling meant more workers. Suquamish tribe chairperson Martha George was born near Maple Valley in Sheridan in 1892
column4: at a logging camp where her mother and grandmother worked as cooks."The town grew inward. Blacksmith shops
column6: saloons and stores took up the town in the 1910s and 1920s. Schools went up as well. Early schools were shacks at best. A two-room school went up in 1910
column7: and a larger high school was built in 1929 as the first school in the Tahoma School District. The school
column9: still stands today as an elementary school. Much of this early development actually did not take place in the modern-day city

column1: More residents meant farming and fishing became staples in the area
column3: poultry and berry farming becoming the main grown food staples in the area. Fishing out of the Cedar River also became popular. Maple Valley also saw resorts beginning in the 1920s. Lake Wilderness
column4: once the site of a county lumber mill
column5: quickly became a resort lake with the opening of Gaffney's Grove
column8: the resort grew to include an airstrip
column11: a nine-hole golf course and a bowling alley. It remained in operation until 1964.Increasing automobile use in the area gave rise to new roads being built. In the early 1960s
column12: the construction of State Route 18 between Auburn and North Bend ran through the city
column13: requiring many landmarks to be either demolished or moved. The Maple Valley Historical Society keeps records on the city's past
column14: with two historical museums holding artifacts such as the city's first fire engine and photographs of old places in and around the city like Gaffney's Grove.

column1: The city of Maple Valley was officially incorporated on August 31
column2: 1997. The Green to Cedar River trail runs through the city
column3: along SR 169 and Witte Road while passing through the former Gaffney's Grove site
column4: now the Lake Wilderness City Park. The park includes a swimming beach and sprawling grass fields
column5: and sees the annual Maple Valley Days Parade each year in June. The Lake Wilderness Arboretum is also located here.Due to the urban growth boundaries of King County
column6: the city is uniquely split into different sectors along Maple Valley Highway (SR 169)
column7: the main thoroughfare through the city. At the northern and southern boundaries of the city lie two large commercial areas
column8: while central Maple Valley is predominantly residential.The south side's Four Corners district is the main commercial area of the city. It is located along Maple Valley Highway and is bisected by Kent-Kangley Road (SR 516) to create four distinct areas of development. The northwestern corner underwent massive reconstruction in the early 2010s and now features several large retailers
column10: and a strip mall. The northeastern corner was completely constructed in the 2010s; it formerly was a large lumberyard and is now home to several retailers. The southern corners feature strip malls

column1: The city is entirely served by the Tahoma School District
column2: which at one point had its high school in neighboring Covington. In 2015
column3: a bond measure was passed to build a new and more centralized high school for the district. It was to be built in a small unincorporated area southeast of Four Corners that was completely surrounded by Maple Valley
column4: known informally as the ‘Donut Hole’. The area was annexed into Maple Valley and the new three-story Tahoma High School was completed in 2017.

column1: The entirety of Maple Valley is served by the Tahoma School District. There is one high school
column3: and six elementary schools. The district operates its transportation facility adjacent to SR 18 on Petrovitsky near city limits. The Central Services building is located next to Rock Creek Elementary School.Most of the district's schools are located within the city

column1: Maple Valley is a contract city with the King County Sheriff's Office for police services. The King County deputies that are assigned to the city wear city uniforms and patches
column2: but wear a King County Sheriff badge. The deputies mostly drive marked patrol cars with the city logo.
